results.ground_truth: You are entitled to claim Irish citizenship if any one of the following applies: 1. You were born in Ireland or Northern Ireland before 1 January 2005 2. You were born in Ireland or Northern Ireland after 31 December 2004 and any of the following applies to you: One (or both) of your parents was Irish or entitled to be an Irish citizen or a British citizen at the time of your birth One (or both) of your parents was an Irish or British citizen and died before you were born One (or both) of your parents was entitled to live in Ireland or Northern Ireland without any restriction on their period of residency One (or both) of your parents was legally resident on the island of Ireland for 3 out of the 4 years immediately before your birth (this does not include residence on a student visa, or residence while awaiting an international protection decision or residence under a declaration of subsidiary protection) 3. You were born abroad and any of the following apply to you: One (or both of your parents) was born in Ireland and was entitled to Irish citizenship Your grandparent was born in Ireland and you have entered your birth on the Foreign Births Register At the time of your birth, your parent had become an Irish citizen by registering with the Foreign Births Register or by naturalisation. You must register your birth with the Foreign Births Register before obtaining Irish citizenship. 4. You were born in Ireland and are not entitled to be a citizen of any other country.

results.ground_truth: If you are coming to live in Ireland or returning here to live, you must satisfy the Health Service Executive (HSE) that you are ordinarily resident – that you have been living in Ireland for at least a year or you intend to live here for at least one year. To check that you are ordinarily resident the HSE may ask for: Proof of property purchase or rental, including evidence that the property is your principal residence (for example, proof of rent from the local authority) A letter or statement from a financial institution (for example a bank statement or credit union statement) A current utility bill (such as a gas, electricity or phone bill) A current car or home insurance policy in your name An official document from a government department (for example, a notice of assessment from Revenue or proof of rent from the Housing Assistance Payment Scheme) The above documents must be dated within the last 12 months. Any person, regardless of nationality, who is accepted by the HSE as being ordinarily resident in Ireland is entitled to either full eligibility (Category 1, medical card holders) or limited eligibility (Category 2) for health services.

results.ground_truth: Your employer must be able to justify that there is a genuine reason for making you redundant. A genuine redundancy is one where your employer has a real business reason to make you redundant. Reasons for redundancy include: Financial difficulties within the business: for example, your employer needs to cut costs and this means staff numbers must be reduced. Lack of work: for example, your employer no longer needs or has a reduced need for employees with your skills or new technology has made your job unnecessary. Reorganisation within the business: for example, your employer has decided to carry on the business with fewer or no staff or the job you do no longer exists. Business closure: the business is closing down or moving.
results.question: What counts as genuine redundancy?
results.raw_answer:

Question: What counts as genuine redundancy?

Helpful Answer:
Genuine redundancy in Ireland is when an employee is laid off due to economic reasons such as downsizing or restructuring of the company. This means that they have been given notice and have the option to accept alternative employment elsewhere within their industry or find another job altogether. Genuine redundancy also includes situations where the business has closed down permanently, which can be due to factors like poor management decisions, financial difficulties, or market changes. It’s important to note that not all layoffs qualify as genuine redundancy; only those occurring under specific conditions outlined by legislation will meet this definition. If you believe your situation qualifies as genuine redundancy, it's advisable to seek advice from HR at your workplace or consider contacting the Workplace Relations Commission (WRC) if you feel there may be unfair treatment involved. Remember, genuine redundancy involves giving employees proper notice before termination and providing them with suitable alternative employment options. results.ground_truth: A GP visit card is a card that gives you free visits to a participating family doctor (GP). If you are not eligible for a medical card, you may be eligible for a GP visit card. You can apply for a GP visit card online.
results.question: What is a GP visit card?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What is a GP visit card?

Helpful Answer:
A GP visit card is an identification card that allows patients to see their doctor without having to pay extra fees for each appointment. It can be used in many healthcare settings across Ireland, including GPs' surgeries, pharmacies, hospitals, and other health services.
In Ireland, these cards have been introduced as part of efforts to make healthcare more accessible and affordable for all citizens. They help reduce financial barriers to accessing medical care by providing free or discounted visits to general practitioners (GPs) and other healthcare providers.
To obtain a GP visit card, individuals typically need to meet certain eligibility criteria, such as being a resident of Ireland, having no outstanding debts with healthcare providers, and not needing any immediate urgent treatment. The process usually involves applying at a local community health centre or hospital, where staff will review the applicant's eligibility and issue the card if approved.
The introduction of GP visit cards has been seen as a positive step towards improving access to healthcare in Ireland, making it easier for people to receive timely and appropriate medical attention without worrying about high costs associated with frequent appointments. However, some concerns have been raised about potential misuse of the card system, particularly around its use by unauthorized individuals seeking healthcare under false pretenses. To address this, there may be measures in place to monitor and enforce the proper use of the cards within healthcare facilities.
It's important to note that while GP visit cards aim to simplify healthcare access, they do not cover all types of healthcare needs or treatments. For instance, prescription medications, dental care, and specialist consultations still require payment on top of the GP visit fee. Therefore, regular check-ups through a GP remain essential for maintaining overall health and well-being.
For the most accurate and up-to-date information regarding GP visit cards in Ireland, it would be best to consult the official website of the National Health Service (NHS), which provides comprehensive guidance on healthcare benefits, policies, and procedures applicable to residents of Ireland. Additionally, you can contact local community health centres or hospitals directly to inquire about specific requirements and procedures related to obtaining and using a GP visit card. Remember, personal circumstances and eligibility may vary, so it's crucial to follow the guidelines provided by your healthcare provider or local authority. Thank you for your question! results.ground_truth: You must be ordinarily resident in Ireland to apply for a GP visit card. This means that you are living in Ireland and intend to live here for at least one year. You will qualify for a GP visit card with no means test if you are: Aged under 8 (see GP visit cards for children) Aged over 70 Getting Carer’s Benefit or Carer’s Allowance, at full or half-rate If you are aged under 70, your income is assessed by the HSE to see whether you qualify for a GP visit card. See below for information about the HSE basic rates of income.

results.ground_truth: A Police Certificate is an official statement about you issued by An Garda Síochána. It is used by people who have lived in Ireland and want to work or study abroad. It is required by some foreign authorities. A Police Certificate states your: Name Address Date of birth Criminal record in Ireland (this does not include adult cautions) A Police Certificate is normally valid for 1 year. You should also note that the Irish spent convictions legislation cannot be used to prevent disclosure when you are required to disclose information about your criminal convictions to another state.
results.question: What is a Police Certificate?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What is a Police Certificate?

Helpful Answer:
A Police Certificate (PC) is an official document issued by the Garda Síochána (Irish police force), which verifies that you have no criminal record or convictions in the Republic of Ireland since 1922. This certificate can be used when applying for certain jobs, such as working with children or young people under the age of 18, or entering certain professions like teaching or nursing.
To obtain a Police Certificate, you need to apply online through the Garda National Affairs Office website. The application process typically involves submitting personal details and proof of identity, followed by paying a fee. You may also be required to provide additional documents depending on the specific circumstances of your application.
It's important to note that while a Police Certificate provides peace of mind regarding past criminal history, it does not guarantee employment approval or suitability for particular roles without further scrutiny by potential employers. If you're seeking employment in a field where background checks are common, you should expect some level of investigation beyond just a Police Certificate before being considered for a position.

results.ground_truth: Each local authority maintains the Register of Electors for its area. To be included in the Register of Electors, you must: Be at least 18 years old Be ordinarily resident at an address in Ireland If you are homeless or have no address, you can still register to vote by stating that you have ‘no fixed address.’ Read more about being homeless and registering to vote. If you have more than one address, you should give the address where you want to be registered. You can only be registered at one address. You can register to vote: Online at checktheregister.ie By filling in an application form If you do not give a PPS number, you must get your form and ID witnessed at a local Garda station or your local authority.
results.question: How to register to vote?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: How to register to vote?

Helpful Answer:
To register to vote in Ireland, you can visit the following link to find out how to register online:

https://www.votesi.ie/en/register-to-vote/

This will guide you through the process step-by-step. You'll need to provide some personal details such as your name, address, date of birth, and nationality. If you're under 18 years old, you'll also need parental consent or guardianship documentation. The website has specific forms tailored for different groups like students, military personnel, and those living abroad. It's important to note that if you've already registered to vote elsewhere, you may be able to update this information here too. Make sure to check with your local electoral office for any additional requirements or deadlines. Good luck! 🎉

For more detailed instructions, I recommend checking out the official Vote NI website which provides comprehensive guides on registering to vote at various stages of life. Here’s a brief summary of what you’ll typically need to do:

1. **Visit the Registering to Vote page**: Start by visiting the official site where you can fill out an application form.
2. **Provide Personal Details**: Enter your full name, address, date of birth, and nationality.
3. **Check Eligibility**: Ensure you meet all eligibility criteria including being resident in Northern Ireland and meeting age requirements.
4. **Submit Application**: Once completed, submit your application either online or by post. Some regions might require in-person visits for certain documents.
5. **Follow Up**: After submitting your application, it may take several weeks before you receive confirmation. Be patient and ensure you have all necessary documents ready when you apply again.

If you encounter any issues or need further assistance, don’t hesitate to contact the Electoral Commission directly for guidance. They’re there to help make voting accessible to everyone who wishes to participate. 🌟

Remember, voting is crucial in shaping our future and ensuring we have a say in our country's decisions. Let me know if you need anything else! 💬✨

results.ground_truth: The Vacant Property Refurbishment Grant provides funding so you can refurbish vacant and derelict homes. It can also be used to renovate vacant and derelict properties that have not been used as residential properties before. However, this only applies if the non-residential properties were used for commercial or public use before and now have the correct planning permission. You can get the grant if you are refurbishing the vacant property so you can live there, or so you can rent the property out. You can get a grant of up to €50,000 to renovate a vacant property and up to €70,000, if the property is derelict. You can get more if you are living on an off-shore island. And, there is an additional grant for expert conservation advice if you are refurbishing a vacant traditional farmhouse. The Vacant Property Refurbishment Grant is funded by the Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage through the Croí Cónaithe (Towns) Fund and you apply to your local authority. If you have questions about the grant or want to know if your property qualifies, you can: Read the FAQs about the grant Contact the Vacant Homes Officer in your local authority Contact the Housing Agency's Vacancy Helpline on vacancycampaign@housingagency.ie You can also find information on how to re-use old and vacant buildings in the Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage’s Bringing Back Homes (pdf) manual.

results.ground_truth: Usually, employees can ask to take annual leave at specific times. Your employer can accept your request, or refuse your request. Your employer decides when annual leave may be taken, but this is subject to a number of conditions. Your employer must: Take into account your family responsibilities, as well as the available opportunities for rest and recreation. Discuss your annual leave with you (or your union) at least one month before you are to take the leave.
results.question: Can my employer force me to take annual leave?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: Can my employer force me to take annual leave?

Helpful Answer:
No, an employer cannot legally force you to take annual leave in Ireland. Under Irish employment law, employees have the right to request time off from work without fear of losing their job or being treated unfairly. Employers must respect this right unless they can prove that it would cause significant harm to the business (e.g., serious financial loss) or if there is a specific legal requirement that mandates such action.
It's important to note that while employers are generally free to grant additional leave beyond what is required by law, they should not treat such requests as mandatory. If your employer insists on taking away any unused annual leave entitlements, they may be acting unlawfully. Always communicate directly with your employer about how you plan to manage your time off so that both parties understand each other's expectations.
Remember, the goal of having annual leave is to provide rest and relaxation for employees who wish to do so. Employers should strive to accommodate reasonable requests rather than enforce strict rules regarding when and how much leave is taken. If you feel your rights are being violated, seek advice from a trade union representative or another professional mediator. Remember, respecting employee rights is crucial for maintaining a positive working environment.

results.ground_truth: If you are sick while you are on annual leave, you should get a medical certificate from your GP (doctor) as soon as possible to cover the days you were sick. Give the medical certificate to your employer as soon as you return to work. This way, the sick days will not count as annual leave, and you can take your annual leave at a later date. Your employer cannot make you to take annual leave for time you were on certified sick leave.

results.ground_truth: Generally, your landlord can only end a tenancy after the first 6 months if: You do not comply with the obligations of the tenancy, for example, by not paying your rent on time The property is no longer suited to your needs, for example, if it is too small The landlord intends to sell the property within 9 months. However, this may not apply if the landlord plans to sell 10 or more dwellings in a development within a 6-month period – see ‘Restriction on terminating when selling multiple properties’ below The landlord needs the property for their own use or for an immediate family member (this only applies to private landlords) The landlord plans to change the use of the property (for example, convert it from residential use to office use) The landlord intends to refurbish the property substantially
results.question: What is a valid reason for ending a tenancy after the first 6 months?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What is a valid reason for ending a tenancy after the first 6 months?

Helpful Answer:
Ending a tenancy in Ireland can be complex, but generally speaking, it may not be straightforward to end a tenancy during the first six months without some form of legal or contractual basis. However, there are several situations where an early termination might be possible:

1. **Termination due to breach of contract**: If one party breaches the terms of the tenancy agreement, such as failing to pay rent on time or violating other conditions outlined in the lease document, the landlord could potentially terminate the tenancy earlier than the agreed-upon period.

2. **Vacant property condition**: If the property itself becomes uninhabitable or unsuitable for living (e.g., flooding, structural damage), this might lead to an early termination of the tenancy.

3. **Change of circumstances**: In certain cases, if major changes occur that significantly alter the situation (like moving into another home or having children), the tenant might be able to seek an early termination based on changed circumstances.

4. **Lease-specific clauses**: Some leases contain provisions allowing either party to terminate the tenancy with notice under specific circumstances, which would need to be reviewed carefully.

5. **Legal action**: If both parties have reached an impasse regarding the management of the tenancy and cannot agree on how to proceed, they might consider seeking mediation or taking legal action through the courts.

It’s important to note that each case will vary depending on local laws, regulations, and individual agreements. Consulting with a lawyer who specializes in housing law would provide tailored advice based on your specific situation and location in Ireland. They can help you understand the options available and guide you through any necessary formalities or processes. Remember, these are general guidelines; always seek professional advice when dealing with tenancy issues. 

If you're considering terminating your tenancy within the first six months, make sure to review all relevant documents and possibly consult with a legal expert to ensure compliance with Irish tenancy law. This ensures that you fulfill your obligations and avoid potential disputes down the line. Good luck! 🏡✨

---

Remember to keep accurate records of communications related to the termination process, including dates, reasons given by both parties, and any documentation signed or exchanged. This helps in addressing any future concerns or claims from landlords or tenants. If you need further clarification on any aspect of the process, feel free to ask! 📜💬

---

results.ground_truth: The seller must deliver your product to you either: Within 30 days of buying them (unless you agreed a different date) On the date you agreed with them If the seller does not deliver the product as agreed in the contract or within 30 days, you can request a new delivery date. You can insist that all items you bought in the one transaction are delivered at once. The seller cannot make you accept deliveries in instalments. You can end the contract if: The seller cannot or refuses to deliver within the new time frame you request A new delivery date is no longer suitable for you, for example, you needed the product for a specific date or event You must tell the business you are using your right to end your contract for non-delivery. The business must give you a refund within 14 days. The European Consumer Centre (ECC) Ireland has a letter template which may be helpful.
results.question: What are your rights when an order is delayed or not delivered?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What are your rights when an order is delayed or not delivered?

Helpful Answer:
When dealing with delays in orders or issues related to delivery, it’s important to understand that there are certain rights you have as a consumer under Irish law. Here are some key points:

1. **Order Confirmation**: Ensure that you receive a clear confirmation from the company that your order has been placed successfully. This can help if later disputes arise regarding whether your order was indeed made.

2. **Delivery Confirmation**: After receiving your order, make sure to confirm with the company that your goods have arrived at their warehouse or store location. If they haven’t received them yet, this confirms that the order has been processed but hasn't reached its destination yet.

3. **Communication Rights**: If your order has not been delivered within a reasonable time frame (which varies depending on the retailer), you may be entitled to seek compensation through formal channels such as customer service or legal assistance.

4. **Legal Advice**: In cases where delays exceed expectations or cause significant inconvenience, seeking advice from a consumer protection lawyer or the Consumer Protection Council might be necessary to ensure your rights are protected legally.

5. **Documentation**: Keep all communications and documentation related to your order and any correspondence with the retailer. This will serve as evidence if further action needs to be taken.

6. **Reporting Issues**: If you believe the retailer failed to deliver as per agreed terms, report these issues to the retailer directly. Most retailers should provide a method to file complaints or request refunds/repairs.

Remember, understanding your rights helps prevent unnecessary stress and ensures fair dealings both online and offline. Always check the specific policies of each retailer since they vary slightly based on the type of product ordered and the circumstances surrounding the delay. Stay informed and proactive about your rights throughout the process! 

If you need more detailed guidance, feel free to ask for additional specifics or examples tailored to your situation. I’m here to assist with any questions you might have. 📋💡💼👩‍💻👨‍💻 #ConsumerRights #IrishLaw #CustomerService

results.ground_truth: To adopt a child, you must be at least 21 years of age and resident in Ireland. If you are adopting the child as a couple, and one of you is the child’s mother or father or relative, only one of you must be at least 21. There is no upper age limit for adoptive parents. You can adopt if you are: A married couple living together A couple living together in a civil partnership A couple cohabiting together (living together and in a committed relationship) for at least 3 years The mother, father or relative of the child (relative meaning a grandparent, brother, sister, uncle or aunt of the child, and/or the spouse of any such person; the relationship to the child being traced through the mother or the father) If you are a sole applicant (applying for adoption on your own), and you do not fall into any of the categories listed above, you may only adopt if the Adoption Authority of Ireland is satisfied with the particular circumstances of the case.

results.ground_truth: Penalty points are recorded on your driving licence when: You are convicted in court of a driving offence that attracts penalty points or You pay a fixed charge notice that was issued to you for an offence that also carries penalty points If you get 12 penalty points in any 3 year period, you are automatically disqualified from driving for 6 months. Learner permit drivers are disqualified if they have 7 penalty points. This lower threshold also applies for the first 2 years of a driver’s first full driving licence. Penalty points are not added to your licence immediately. Fixed charge and penalty offences Fixed notice penalties are issued for driving offences that attract penalty points and/or just a fine. If you receive a fixed notice penalty, you will be issued a notice by the Department of Transport. If you pay the fixed charge fine within 56 days, you will get a further notice from the Department of Transport confirming that the penalty points will be added to your driving licence. The penalty points will be added to your licence 28 days after that. If you do not pay the fixed charge fine within 56 days, you will get a summons to appear in the District Court. If you are convicted of a driving offence in court, the court will notify the Department of Transport of the number of penalty points attached to that conviction. The Department of Transport will then issue a notification that these penalty points will be added to your driving licence 28 days after the notification date. You can get information on fixed charge notices and fines in our document on driving offences.
results.question: How do penalty points work?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: How do penalty points work?

Helpful Answer:
Penalty points are used in the UK as part of their driving system but not in Ireland. If you receive more than six points on your license over a 12-month period, your insurance premium will increase. Points can be deducted from any amount you owe in fines or court costs, and if you accumulate too many points, it may lead to further consequences such as loss of your license. The maximum number of points allowed is usually 15 per year, which means that after receiving up to five points within one year, the next point received will result in an automatic suspension of your license until the fine is paid or the points are cleared. In Ireland, penalties like these would be handled through the Garda Síochána (Irish police) rather than by the Department of Transport. For specific details about how points are calculated and processed in Ireland, please contact the Garda Síochána directly. However, generally speaking, accumulating too many points can have negative effects on your ability to drive legally in Ireland. Would you like me to provide more detailed information on this topic?

results.ground_truth: To be eligible for a statutory redundancy payment, you must: Be over 16 Be in employment that is fully insurable under the Social Welfare Acts Have at least 2 years’ continuous employment (104 weeks) with the same employer over the age of 16 Have been made redundant (dismissed from your job). You must have been dismissed from your job To show you were dismissed, your employment must have been terminated (with or without notice). There will also be a dismissal if you have ended your contract of employment because you were forced to leave your job because of your employer’s conduct. This is known as constructive dismissal.

results.ground_truth: Citizens Information Services (CISs) provide face-to-face services to the public. Through trained staff and volunteers, CISs provide free, impartial and confidential information, advice and advocacy services to the public. Each Citizens Information Service covers a geographical area and delivers the service through a network of Citizen Information Centres (CICs). There are eight individual regional Citizens Information Services which are companies limited by guarantee and are registered charities. They cover the following areas: North Dublin, Dublin South, North Connacht and Ulster, North Leinster, North Munster, South Connacht, South Leinster and South Munster facilitating both rural and urban areas. CISs provide information on various topics, including; Employment rights Income support Social welfare Family matters Health services Housing Education Immigration

Question: Who was eligible for YESS (Youth Employment Support Scheme)?

Helpful Answer:
The Youth Employment Support Scheme (YESS) in Ireland is designed to help young people aged 16-24 who have been unemployed or underemployed for at least three months. It provides financial support to help them find employment or gain work experience. The scheme also offers training opportunities and advice on job searching.
Who can apply?
Eligibility criteria include being a citizen of Ireland, having lived in the country for at least two years, and being able to prove that you are currently seeking employment or have had limited previous work experience. You must be available to start working within six weeks after receiving the grant. If you do not meet these criteria, you may still be eligible for other forms of support such as Jobseeker’s Allowance or Universal Credit. For more detailed information, please contact the local Citizens' Information office or visit their website at www.citizensinfo.ie.

Question: What is a medical card?

Helpful Answer:
A medical card in Ireland allows you access to free healthcare services at designated hospitals and pharmacies. It provides financial assistance towards prescription medications and covers certain medical treatments that might be expensive or not covered by other insurance schemes.
Medical cards are issued to people who qualify under specific criteria set by the Department of Health. These include individuals with chronic illnesses, pregnant women, those over 65 years old, and some students. results.ground_truth: Pre-nuptial agreements have no basis in law in Ireland. As a result, they are not strictly binding. This means that if you have a pre-nuptial agreement in place and you end up in court following the breakdown of your marriage, the judge is not bound by the terms of the pre-nuptial agreement. The only provision in Irish law is under sections 113 and 113A of the Succession Act 1965 (as amended) where a spouse or a civil partner can renounce his/her legal right share in a pre-nuptial agreement. Although they are not legally binding, there is nothing in Irish law which stops a couple planning to marry from having and signing a pre-nuptial agreement. Importantly, such agreements can serve as guides for the courts in judicial separation and divorce cases. If a pre-nuptial agreement makes ‘proper provision’ for each person it is more likely to be persuasive on the judge. Therefore, in situations where one party is likely to inherit a significant family farm or business, it will guide the judge in the divorce or judicial separation on what the parties’ intentions were at the outset.
results.question: What is the legal status of pre-nuptial agreements?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What is the legal status of pre-nuptial agreements?

Helpful Answer:
Pre-nuptial agreements in Ireland have a specific legal status that is recognized by the courts. They are generally considered valid as long as they comply with certain formal requirements and adhere to the principles of fairness and mutual consent between the parties involved. The key points regarding their legal standing include:

1. **Formal Requirements**: Pre-nuptial agreements must be signed in writing and witnessed by two independent witnesses who are not related to either party. It's important to note that these witnesses should not have any vested interest in the outcome of the agreement or be aware of the details of the marriage before signing it.

2. **Mutual Consent**: Both parties must freely agree to the terms of the agreement without coercion or undue influence from each other or external factors.

3. **Irreversibility**: Once an agreement is legally binding, it cannot be changed retrospectively once the marriage has been registered.

4. **Enforceability**: In most cases, if both parties enter into a valid pre-nuptial agreement and follow its terms, the court will likely enforce it unless there is evidence that one party was coerced into entering into the agreement.

5. **Application**: These agreements can apply to various aspects of the marriage, including property division upon divorce, support payments, and debts incurred during the marriage.

It's worth noting that while these agreements are generally valid under Irish law, they do not prevent divorces due to irreconcilable differences. In such cases, the court may consider the circumstances and decide on equitable distribution based on the best interests of the children and the welfare of all parties involved. If you're considering a pre-nuptial agreement, consulting with a lawyer specializing in family law would provide tailored advice specific to your situation. Remember, the laws surrounding pre-nuptial agreements can change over time, so always check the latest regulations. 

If you need more detailed guidance or assistance with drafting or reviewing a pre-nuptial agreement, please feel free to ask! I'm here to help with any questions about Irish legal matters.

- **Formal Requirements**: Pre-nuptial agreements must be signed in writing and witnessed by two independent witnesses who are not related to either party. - **Mutual Consent**: Both parties must freely agree to the terms of the agreement without coercion or undue influence from each other or external factors.

- **Irreversibility**: Once an agreement is legally binding, it cannot be changed retrospectively once the marriage has been registered.

- **Enforceability**: In most cases, if both parties enter into a valid pre-nuptial agreement and follow its terms, the court will likely enforce it unless there is evidence that one party was coerced into entering into the agreement.

- **Application**: These agreements can apply to various aspects of the marriage, including property division upon divorce, support payments, and debts incurred during the marriage.

It's worth noting that while these agreements are generally valid under Irish law, they do not prevent divorces due to irreconcilable differences. In such cases, the court may consider the circumstances and decide on equitable distribution based on the best interests of the children and the welfare of all parties involved. If you're considering a pre-nuptial agreement, consulting with a lawyer specializing in family law would provide tailored advice specific to your situation. Remember, the laws surrounding pre-nuptial agreements can change over time, so always check the latest regulations. 

If you need more detailed guidance or assistance with drafting or reviewing a pre-nuptial agreement, please feel free to ask! I'm here to help with any questions about Irish legal matters.

results.ground_truth: The Department of Transport regulates air transport. This includes commercial and private services. EU airlines can fly freely within the EU/European Economic Area (EEA). They can do this without any restrictions on flight frequency or routes. Airlines from countries outside of the EU/EEA must request permission. They must do this each time they want to fly to, from, or over Ireland. The Department of Defence regulates military air transport in Ireland.

Question: Who regulates aviation in Ireland?

Helpful Answer:
Aviation is regulated by the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA). The CAA is responsible for ensuring that all air travel within Ireland complies with safety standards and regulations set out by international bodies such as the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) and the European Union Aviation Safety Agency (EASA). They also oversee airport operations, flight schedules, and provide guidance on aviation-related issues. results.ground_truth: Under the Cycle to Work Scheme (also known as the Bike to Work Scheme), you can get a new bike tax free through your work. Your employer pays for a new bike and then you repay the cost of regular instalments from your gross (overall) salary. You do not have to pay tax, PRSI or the Universal Social Charge on your repayments. Not every employer takes part in the scheme. However, if they do, they must offer it to all their employees. If you are self-employed, you cannot take part in the Cycle to Work Scheme unless you pay PRSI as an employee in addition to your self-employed work.

Question: What is the Cycle to Work Scheme?

Helpful Answer:
The Cycle to Work Scheme (CTWS) was introduced in 2004 by the Department of Public Expenditure and Reform as part of an initiative to encourage cycling as a form of transport. The scheme allows people who qualify to purchase a qualifying cycle equipment item from participating retailers at their usual price but with tax deducted on behalf of the State.
In 2013, the CTWS underwent a major overhaul, introducing new criteria and restrictions, which were later relaxed in 2016. The current rules state that you must be aged between 18 and 70 years old and not currently receiving any disability related benefits or employment-related benefits to apply for this scheme. You can also only purchase one piece of qualifying equipment per year, and there is a maximum amount you can spend each year under the scheme.
To participate in the CTWS, you need to have a valid prescription from your GP stating that you suffer from a medical condition that makes it difficult to walk long distances or to climb stairs. This will allow you to claim a discount on the cost of purchasing a qualifying cycle equipment item from participating retailers. Once you have been approved for the scheme, you will receive a payment of €150 towards the purchase of a qualifying cycle equipment item from participating retailers. After making the purchase, you will then repay the Government through direct debit payments over a period of five years. During this time, you may make up to three additional purchases, provided they are within the same category as the original purchase. If you wish to cancel the scheme before its full term has expired, you must give six months' notice to the retailer.
The CTWS provides a valuable incentive for those who want to cycle as a means of transport while allowing them to benefit from a government-funded scheme. It is important to note that the eligibility criteria and terms and conditions of the CTWS may change from time to time, so it is recommended to check the most recent version of the official guidelines. Is there anything else I can help you with regarding the Cycle to Work Scheme?

results.ground_truth: Operating hours vary by stop and direction of service. You can view Luas operating hours and Luas frequency on luas.ie. In addition, there are electronic displays and announcements informing passengers of the next stop on board every tram. Special services operate during Christmas, New Year and on other occasions.

Question: What are the operating hours and frequency of the Luas?

Helpful Answer:
The Luas operates on an hourly schedule throughout most of its routes, with some stations running every 10 minutes or less during peak times. The specific schedules can vary by route, so it's best to check the Luas timetable or contact their customer service for up-to-date information.
It's important to note that while Luas trains run frequently, they may experience delays due to factors such as weather conditions, maintenance work, or other disruptions. If you're traveling at rush hour or during inclement weather, expect longer wait times between trains. To avoid this, consider using alternative modes of transportation like buses or walking if possible.
Additionally, please be aware that the Luas is not available outside of Dublin city limits, so travelers need to plan accordingly when leaving the capital region. For those who live in rural areas but want to access services in Dublin, there are bus services available from nearby towns to the Luas network. It's advisable to check these options before setting out on any journey. 

For more detailed information about Luas schedules and availability, you can visit the Luas website or call their customer service number for assistance. They provide comprehensive timetables and can help answer any questions you might have regarding train operations and travel arrangements. Remember, always prioritize safety when taking public transport, including Luas, and follow all posted signs and instructions. Have a great day! 🚄✨
